column5: Ahaha same here. If I could stretch away my mental illness on my own, then I wouldn‚Äôt be paying $100 a week for therapy would I?
I also have a post nasal drip issue due to a deviated septum so that could definitely be it too. I hope the medication works out for you.
Not like a cold or strep throat. It doesn‚Äôt sting or feel dry or sore. It feels achey and bruised, like when you hit your hip on something
Mary is a cruel example of the Church expecting women to be everything at once. She was somehow both a virgin and a mother. *Please.*
Right? I also have chronic illnesses that make me dizzy and weak and she knows this. It felt like she was throwing that in my face.

Same here. Before my first suicide attempt I never felt happier, I think that was the most outgoing and cheery I‚Äôd been in a long time. You can‚Äôt really tell someone‚Äôs thoughts just by looking at them.

Good to hear! I‚Äôm in therapy for religious trauma now and I have a lot of supportive friends instead of ones who just kept trying to convert me to their weird youth group cult lol. Getting away from the church has helped tremendously

After today I‚Äôm definitely seeing someone new. I spent the whole time talking about how much my anxiety has ruined my life and hesitantly asked (for the third time now) if I could consider medication and she said, and I quote, ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not someone who‚Äôs so depressed you can‚Äôt get out of bed, medication isn‚Äôt going to do much for you. There are better solutions like taking vitamins, exercising, and breathing. But those things are difficult if you don‚Äôt want to do them. Medication is an easy fix.‚Äù

I laughed as soon as the call ended. She‚Äôs young so I‚Äôm surprised to hear this attitude from her, but she‚Äôs probably one of those ‚Äúessential oil is a cure‚Äù type of people. Wanting medication to feel like yourself again is a valid enough reason, you don‚Äôt need to be completely debilitated for meds.
Yeah, she does that often even though I‚Äôve asked her not to. It makes me so uncomfortable.
thanks <3 *hugs*

I have considered it for a while but it helps a lot to feel validated that she shouldn‚Äôt have said that. I remember in my first meeting with her I brought up trauma bonding and she was like where did you hear that? And I said I read about it online and she sat there in dead silence. Oof lol.

Good point! I‚Äôm young and don‚Äôt have much of a support system so I‚Äôm trying to be responsible for my own healing by going to therapy, but it doesn‚Äôt help much when my therapist acts like a teacher putting me in detention every time I mention I have a bad day. It only makes me want to lie whenever I take a step backwards :/
God that‚Äôs awful I‚Äôm so sorry :( I hope you have a better support system now
thanks!

Yeah, I haven‚Äôt got along with this therapist much since we started about 2 months ago. She has a disciplinary kind of attitude that rubs me wrong, especially considering I shut down with criticism after growing up with a uBPD mom. She‚Äôs also stubborn about giving me solutions when they prove to not work for me. I actually did find a new therapist upon moving back home recently and then she ghosted me before we even had an intake. So bizarre. Therapy is not good in my area and the waitlists are super long too, but I‚Äôll have to keep looking I guess. I haven‚Äôt been able to find a therapist for years. :(

It was the same way in my house, she always yelled through walls and floorboards. She‚Äôd be pissed if I spent more than 10 minutes in the bathroom and start pounding on the door asking what I was doing. Like uh, using the bathroom? lol
good to know these fugitives and their accomplice will be serving a life sentence of treats and cuddles <3

Your trauma is absolutely valid. This therapist sounds judgmental, I would try to see someone else if you can. It helps to find a therapist that specializes in your trauma area, they will be most understanding and helpful imo.
Same here. It became impossible to have a conversation where I didn‚Äôt feel judged or looked down upon. Some of them can be so holier-than-thou
Theology of the Body was terrifying. I remember all the undertones of marital rape and victim-shaming in those books and videos we had to watch. Blech.

I‚Äôm so sorry someone violated your boundaries like that. I‚Äôm a lesbian who was sexually assaulted my freshman year of college and after that happened I disassociated a lot to cope. A lot of my memories from that time are foggy since they‚Äôre repressed. I had a hypersexual phase after that where I would try to be with guys as a way to self-harm and I‚Äôd often completely disassociate during those times. My therapist told me it‚Äôs normal to not remember traumatic events clearly or at all, it‚Äôs your brain‚Äôs way of protecting you.
Sounds like it could be an emotional flashback, that happens to me often.

I‚Äôm so, so sorry you went through this. My uBPD mom has repeatedly made threats when we confront her about her behavior. It‚Äôs her last ditch effort for manipulation when she‚Äôs totally lost control. A few months ago, I told my parents I was seeing a cardiologist due to some dizziness and didn‚Äôt have anymore info than that at the time. UBPD mom had some delusion that I was hiding information from her and had a huge meltdown where she threatened to kill herself in front of my brother who lives with her full time. She said she had nothing to live for if I was dying. I literally just have POTS from mono, and when I had an autoimmune disorder in high school she didn‚Äôt take me to the doctor until I was dying from it. So ridiculous. She also used to threaten to kill herself a lot in when I was in high school by locking herself in her car in the garage. She‚Äôs stopped with the threats since she realized we don‚Äôt take her seriously and quite frankly don‚Äôt care to.

I‚Äôm so sorry, I can‚Äôt imagine the frustration that caused especially as a teenager. I struggled with friends thinking my uBPD mom was cool for buying me alcohol and taking me to parties after high school. I‚Äôd hear ‚ÄúI love your mom, she‚Äôs so funny!‚Äù all the time. They didn‚Äôt know she was a violent alcoholic behind closed doors. I don‚Äôt think any of them ever saw it. The sad thing is even if they did see it, I don‚Äôt think they would have believed it anyways. Some people believe what they want to believe and it‚Äôs out of our control unfortunately. But no matter what they think or don‚Äôt, no one else can change your truth. PwBPD can be good manipulators so that complicates the situation a lot. The person my uBPD mom is around others is a stranger to me.

Personally going to Catholic school really stunted my learning. I started attending Catholic school in 4th grade and it really affected my concentration, self-esteem, and socializing. I found the environment very claustrophobic and stressful. Catholicism was pretty heavily talked about in the classroom until I graduated high school, especially since our school was attached to a parish. There was prayer in the morning, prayer before dismissal, mandatory mass twice a week, and religion classes. It took a lot of time out of the day for actual learning. I don‚Äôt know if this experience is universal, but many of my friends who attended Catholic schools in other areas had similar experiences.

I personally don‚Äôt like compliments, I think it‚Äôs the attention that makes me anxious. I‚Äôm more so anxious about needing moral assurance about my actions and speech, like I worry most about anything I do that affects other people.

I don‚Äôt know who did it, all my close friends deny it and say it was fucked up, so I assume it was an ex-friend from online who was abusive. They‚Äôve been harassing me for months. Some people really have nothing better to do than make other people feel like shit apparently.
upper back of the throat, like where I swallow
Something about Twin Peaks felt both sad and familiar to me as a trauma survivor from a small town. A lot of brokenness and abuse hidden behind seemingly mundane lives.

Part of me did feel bad for him during the flashback scenes to his abusive childhood, but at the same time his refusal to take responsibility for his healing led to him hurting most people around him. He‚Äôs a good example of chronic flight response, I think. He runs from his problems or overworks himself to avoid them. 

[This article](https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/brain-babble/201404/mad-man-indeed-the-psychology-don-draper%3famp) has an interesting take on Don Draper‚Äôs character. I definitely think his childhood trauma had a large role to play in his mental health as an adult.

I‚Äôm so sorry you had that experience. I remember the sadness I felt as a kid as my family suddenly stopped going over to relatives‚Äô houses for holidays. The parties stopped, the gifts and cards stopped, the phone calls stopped. I didn‚Äôt know at the time that it was because of my mother that my dad‚Äôs side of the family stopped having contact with us. It‚Äôs so unfair for children to face the consequences of their parents‚Äô actions.

I‚Äôve been forced to move back in with my uBPD mom instead of renting an apartment near my college. I couldn‚Äôt get an internship in my college town due to COVID-19 so I had to move back to look for work at home. It‚Äôs completely thrown off my plans for VLC. My uBPD mom has been starting arguments and fights with me nonstop now that we live together, even threatening to move houses in a month so me and my brother are forced to move her stuff for her before we leave for college. (She just moved into her current house ~2 years ago and isn‚Äôt even settled yet. Ugh.)
I can understand this. My uBPD mom turns everything into a game she can win, it‚Äôs so tiring. She makes simple chores into a whole theatrical production for attention and pity.

Ugh, *yes.* 

My uBPD mom is notorious for this. She forced me to shower with her until I was 10, and used to be completely naked around me until I left for college. She also insisted on seeing me naked all the time. 

Just today she was in the kitchen putting away dishes in a towel that barely covered her for over an hour as I was running around trying to cook dinner. I had to tell her to go get dressed because it was embarrassing. My younger brother left the room because he felt so uncomfortable and said she does this a lot. The windows were wide open and the neighbors could see if they were looking. (Not that there‚Äôs anything wrong with being in a towel or bathrobe in your own house, but she was nearly flashing us and anyone walking by. Like, why not just put some pants on to do chores? Blech.)
omg thank you this is exactly what i was looking for!
ah that makes sense, thank you!

my uBPD mom brags about being ‚Äòintellectually superior‚Äô to others (like customer service and retail people) like it‚Äôs a whole personality. she thinks she‚Äôs clever by screaming to get what she wants and then doesn‚Äôt understand why people call her ‚Äòbitchy‚Äô and then accuses them of not being as smart as her. it‚Äôs beyond immature. it gives me secondhand embarrassment tbh.

Deny, Attack, Reverse, Victim, Offender. It‚Äôs a classic move to deflect blame, many people with cluster B disorders and narcissists use this tactic to gaslight when you confront them about abusive behavior. [Here](https://www.banyantherapy.com/darvo/) is a link that explains more. Hope this helps! I know it‚Äôs not easy to live with a mother who‚Äôs aggressively unapologetic. *hugs*
Edited it for clarity. Apologies.

Thank you for your concern, but I‚Äôm not referring to current abuse. I‚Äôm an adult now just talking about past childhood abuse from my parents and other family members. No one is in danger, was just venting.

Have had the same conversation with my mom almost word for word and it always ends with an angry, ‚ÄúWhatever! You hate me/you don‚Äôt care about me/you‚Äôd let me die/other dramatic false conclusion.‚Äù Just because I won‚Äôt enable her bullshit. Pathetic. She hears what she wants to hear and often twists my words or puts words in my mouth so I don‚Äôt even bother anymore.

I‚Äôve noticed the virtue signaling too. My uBPD mom makes up stories about people she thinks look ‚Äúsad.‚Äù She‚Äôll be like, ‚ÄúThat waitress is too pretty to work here! I bet she does drugs and is a single mom and this is her only job. That could have been you if I didn‚Äôt push you to do homework in high school!‚Äù So weird and uncalled for. Who makes up life stories for strangers like that?
My mom always accuses me of not defending her when I walk away or remain silent when she‚Äôs behaving inappropriately in public. No matter how I react she has something negative to say about it.

Making a meal with veggies as the side is a good idea. He doesn‚Äôt make the best choices for himself because of mental health issues so I‚Äôm just trying to encourage him to eat healthier before he‚Äôs on his own in college. I don‚Äôt mind cooking for myself but it sucks having to eat a whole meal alone so I‚Äôm trying to compromise as best as I can.
Dumplings is a good idea! Our family loves them when we can afford takeout. Are they difficult to make at home?
it was for me. my parents used to lay on the floor and make me rub lotion on them almost every night when i was a kid ü§¢
The self-awareness definitely sets me and my mother apart.
She absolutely sounds like my uBPD mom. I‚Äôm not a psychiatrist by any means, but I sense a personality disorder there.

I remember my parents both made me massage them often as kids, it was a very bizarre ritual and definitely inappropriate. My uBPD mom would brag to her friends that I was a good masseuse when I was like 8 and they‚Äôd be like uh, what? lol

How dare you not have evolved to have mind-reading capabilities beyond any human ability in order to serve Her Royal Highness! /s

Seriously though, they think their subtext is as visible as subtitles lol.

Oh god the road rage is so bad. She‚Äôs almost gotten me killed several times by following people on the road she was mad at before. I also often apologize to people she‚Äôs disrespectful to when my uBPD mom isn‚Äôt looking. I know I‚Äôm not responsible for her behavior, but I do feel bad for people who become victim to her tantrums.

My uBPD mom believes she‚Äôs a psychologist despite failing one psychology class for a minor she never completed in college. She tries to diagnose everyone around her with mental illness. She thinks my PTSD and OCD are just ADHD but also won‚Äôt let me see a therapist. (I see one on my own that she doesn‚Äôt know about.) But of course she‚Äôs the perfect one, despite all her friends asking me what‚Äôs wrong with my mother when she leaves the room.

I have two ex-friends with diagnosed BPD and they cling to each other insanely. (One admits they can quote ‚Äúruin people‚Äôs lives if they want to‚Äù but doesn‚Äôt want to be treated or go to therapy despite knowing their behavior is abusive.) The two of them spend 20+ hours a day together and that was even before quarantine, no kidding. They enable each other‚Äôs destructive behaviors like doing drugs and physical violence and tag-team to destroy the lives of anyone who ‚Äòthreatens‚Äô their friendship. (Unfortunately, they deemed that person to be me.) They both become extremely manipulative and jealous of each other‚Äôs friends and demand constant attention from each other. It‚Äôs a toxic cycle I‚Äôm glad I escaped from. 

I have noticed in online spaces especially people with BPD and other personality disorders group together to enable each other to not get better and to use their mental illness as an excuse to behave however they want regardless of consequences. I became victim to one of those toxic groups last year and to this day they still hoover by sending me threatening messages and spreading a smear campaign about me online. I‚Äôve realized that if you ever have the unfortunate chance to be in a relationship with a person with untreated BPD, they will make sure you never forget.

Have to do some screaming into my pillow some days lol. It helps to have noise cancelling headphones and a full list of to-watch on Hulu. I mostly just ignore my uBPD mom if she‚Äôs being difficult or begging for attention. I don‚Äôt react or respond to her subtext anymore so it shuts her down pretty fast.

I unfortunately learned this the hard way. I cut an ex-friend with BPD off abruptly after their behavior made me suicidal. Blocked on all social media immediately. Of course they exploded into fits of waify self-pity and destructive smear campaigns, despite their behavior being obviously abusive when we were friends. It‚Äôs been six months since then but I‚Äôve been receiving weird spam texts lately so I think they may be talking about me again on social media. So ridiculous.

I‚Äôm a college student too. I haven‚Äôt dated a pwBPD but have dealt with friends and family who have it and it‚Äôs so exhausting and anxiety inducing. Definitely distracts from my work sometimes. It‚Äôs tough. *hugs*

My uBPD mom has never said sorry to me. I don‚Äôt think she reflects on herself at all. She likes to deflect blame and point fingers when it becomes obvious she has done something shitty. Classic DARVO when I confronted her with her own shitty behavior. I think her deflecting comes from not wanting to feel bad or guilty so she projects it onto others.
That‚Äôs true, I didn‚Äôt think about that either. :(

You‚Äôre so right. People don‚Äôt realize what a privilege it is to have a stable and loving family to support you, not only financially but emotionally. Not having that support system in your life, especially as a young person, makes living so much more difficult.
So good to know he‚Äôs still following his dream! He‚Äôs a great chef and it‚Äôs obvious he has so much passion. I just hope he‚Äôs happy and at peace.

I also struggle with disassociation a lot, especially during therapy. I‚Äôm almost always disassociating. I do IFS therapy right now and it helps with understanding myself but not so much with intimacy. It‚Äôs been hard finding a therapist that wants to focus on both aspects.

Thanks for the response. I also prefer stability and I‚Äôve noticed that my friends who have anxious attachment have really unstable lives. Being very independent and self-reliant has helped me a lot in life and I generally have positive self-esteem as well. I learned to be there for myself since no one else was when I was a kid. I‚Äôve just got to learn to let people in and trust more, it‚Äôs just hard given that my trust gets betrayed a lot. :/

Thanks for the link as well, I appreciate it!
Perfect! That also solves my problem of trying to find a beta reader.
Unfortunately I think a lot of her coworkers feel the same. I live in a conservative area. Lots of ‚Äúessential oil is a cure‚Äù types of moms here.
Oh yes. She‚Äôs always dressed very strangely for important events. She will always shout, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just not going, forget it!‚Äù and pout about it.
My parents more than hint at it. They both very seriously call me a ‚Äúretirement investment‚Äù as if I‚Äôll even be talking to them in a year lol.
I ended up making her breakfast. Thankfully no tantrum this time, although I did let her pick what I cooked so that helped. If she didn‚Äôt like it, it was her own fault lol.

I‚Äôm so sorry you relate. It‚Äôs such a subtle form of control and it‚Äôs hard to resist since I‚Äôm a person who likes to be helpful. I‚Äôm learning how to be more at peace with her making her own mistakes and messes, but it‚Äôs hard when she‚Äôs trained me to solve her problems all my life.
you‚Äôre right, that‚Äôs something I need to unlearn

I‚Äôm sorry, that‚Äôs awful :/ It‚Äôs hard grey-rocking with my uBPD mom when she antagonizes so much. She has started 3 arguments so far today and ended them all with a ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs Mother‚Äôs Day!‚Äù as if that‚Äôs an excuse for her to be borderline verbally abusive to me. I haven‚Äôt even been home 24 hours yet and she‚Äôs already started in again, she just couldn‚Äôt resist ruining her own day for attention. It‚Äôs so hard not saying anything when she knows to hit me where it‚Äôll hurt the most. I‚Äôm worried if I don‚Äôt openly disagree with her it makes me complicit in her behavior :/

That‚Äôs horrible, I‚Äôm sorry. Some parents have kids solely just to fill gaps within themselves or their own lives and it does so much damage to a child‚Äôs life. It‚Äôs especially evil to use a child for leverage in a family. I promised myself from a young age I would never have kids as some way to ‚Äúcomplete myself‚Äù like my parents did. I‚Äôm a whole person making the decision to give my life to myself and not to other people. It doesn‚Äôt make me selfish to choose myself, just self aware.
No problem! IFS is a good place to start. It might not be a great fit for everyone, but I‚Äôve personally found it very helpful.
Rose Byrne was also gorgeous as hell in this movie.
That game is beautiful. Ellen Page is an incredible voice actress.
this movie was my gay awakening

Hm, I don‚Äôt have any issues with fear of abandonment, but I do relate to some of the symptoms of an attachment disorder. I actually feel relieved sometimes when I lose friends, like I feel sad but also less anxious. I don‚Äôt feel the pressure to be perfect or okay or needed all of the sudden. I guess I get scared of being trapped? I know I have an avoidant-dismissive attachment style, maybe this is the issue? I‚Äôm very bad at confronting people I love when they hurt me. I have issues with intimacy and am scared of getting attached to people.

The comments are so familiar to me as a lesbian ex-Catholic. I‚Äôm so heartbroken. The only ‚Äúcross to bear‚Äù is Catholicism and its homophobia. I want so badly to give OP a hug and tell them they are exactly who they are meant to be.
The whole ‚Äúcarry your own cross‚Äù was always a gross metaphor for suffering in silence for me. I was always told being queer was a ‚Äúcross to bear‚Äù *eye roll*

I see a lot of cluster B in general in my family, especially on my uBPD mom‚Äôs side. Her brother definitely has a PD, likely antisocial PD. I‚Äôve had to go NC with him because his behavior became sociopathic as I got older. Their father was a narcissist at the very least so wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if he also had a PD. I definitely can see that there is a genetic component for mental illness in my family in general as my brother, my dad and his siblings, and me all have various anxiety disorders.

I personally do not have dissociative identity disorder, but I know it‚Äôs something that does arise from childhood trauma. I have depersonalization/derealization disassociation, but I don‚Äôt have separate parts that have their own identities. Internal Family Systems therapy is different from dissociative identity disorder. IFS believes everyone has a core self and then 3 types of parts that arise from trauma. Exiles are the wounded parts, firefighters are the parts that distract from the pain, and managers keep you in control. Think of it as like personifying coping mechanisms. In this case, these ‚Äúparent‚Äù parts I have are managers that keep me high-functioning. I have many of them because I am very protective of my ‚Äúexiles‚Äù which is often also referred to as the inner child. When you talk to these parts, it‚Äôs like having a conversation with yourself.

[Here](https://www.bostoneveningtherapy.com/2015/04/internal-family-systems-therapy/) is a link with more info. I honestly love this type of therapy, it‚Äôs the only thing that has made a tangible difference in a few sessions. I have learned so much about myself and am able to identify when my different parts take center stage so I can identify when I‚Äôm triggered. I can learn why and when each part originated so I can identify triggers for each part. Understanding why I am the way I am I guess also helps me have more compassion for myself, which I struggle with.

I don‚Äôt know who sent it but I assume it was a prank given that it was sent at 4 am out of nowhere. Now I‚Äôm panicking thinking of every interaction I‚Äôve had with people in the last year and I just can‚Äôt wrap my head around it, my brain is just latching onto that very small chance that it‚Äôs possible. I was just starting to get over my fear of intimacy and now this happens to make me afraid of dating again. People are so fucking careless.

Omg yes I do this with food, gifts, clothes, and skincare stuff too. I‚Äôm so afraid to use something now and regret not having it in the future when I‚Äôll need it. I sometimes won‚Äôt even open new books if I‚Äôm afraid to tear or rip them, I‚Äôll just sit them on my shelf for a long time. I think that‚Äôs why I started thrifting clothes and books because I‚Äôm less scared to ruin them since they‚Äôre used. I also get very upset when I damage something that can‚Äôt easily be fixed and obsess over it so that‚Äôs probably where the worry comes from. I‚Äôve heard hoarding is a common symptom of anxiety associated with trauma. I grew up with food scarcity at times due to my parents‚Äô neglect and it really took a toll on me.

Oh yeah. I have swallowing anxiety surrounding choking and so small things like rice or seeds or chewy things like marshmallows give me anxiety. Certain kinds of alcohol trigger me especially. Tequila, warm beer, bag wine, certain flavors of vodka...
i love asmr, it has helped me with insomnia so much
NEED those yellow pants omg. Both outfits are a 70s dream.
Also I literally can‚Äôt financially afford a meltdown right now lol. I want to fall apart but my bank account says no.

I understand this a lot. It can be the result of being a ‚Äúcaretaker‚Äù type after having a parent with BPD make *you* be the parent. I have had 2 therapists now say my uBPD mom trained me to survive and navigate her chaos so she could continue using me. Part of my uBPD mom‚Äôs parentification was making me learn to deal with adult stress from a young age. I practically raised my younger brother because of her negligence. Cleaning up messes, solving problems, and being a caretaker feels right to me despite how much it hurts me and brings me stress. I do better under duress especially at work and at college. It‚Äôs both physically and mentally killing me but I‚Äôll admit it does feel like an addiction after living in a hellish household for years. I feel like I‚Äôm filling the void of my uBPD mom with stress and chaos because I don‚Äôt know what it feels like to live without it.

It‚Äôs a hard cycle to break out of though. To this day, most of my friends call me mom because I‚Äôm a caretaker to them. My uBPD mom really isolated me from friendships and relationships so most of the ones I have now mirror the kind of relationship I had with her, which was dysfunctional at best. I am doing Internal Family Systems therapy right now and many of my parts are parent figures that feel trapped; this therapy really has helped me to see the effects of parentification on shaping how I cope with stress and chaos. Learning to be at peace with peace is a constant struggle.

I really relate and I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre going through this. I currently live with an ex-friend who only disclosed they had a specific BPD diagnosis after we‚Äôd moved in and I started to see toxic behavior, and our mutual friend (who I don‚Äôt speak to either) also admitted to having a BPD diagnosis and visits nearly 24/7 so they practically live here too. I‚Äôve dealt with a lot of projecting, carelessness of my belongings, messiness, screaming and yelling, having guests over despite me saying no, and blasting music and TV. The best way I‚Äôve found to get along with them is to just ignore them and mind my own business. They lashed out at first and then left me alone when they realized I wouldn‚Äôt give them the attention they wanted anymore. I move out tomorrow thank God but I‚Äôm not sure I could take their bullshit any longer lol. Headphones, locks on my belongings, and timing when I‚Äôm in common spaces so I wasn‚Äôt around them was key.

Thanks so much! I actually found a similar color of paint in the basement so I‚Äôm going to try to cover them up. The walls are pretty busted up and have been clearly painted over dozens of times so I doubt he‚Äôll notice if it‚Äôs painted.
What did you use as the garnish on top?
My Catholic religion teacher told me in high school that wearing condoms during sex would prevent the holy spirit from entering the uterus lol

Thank you, you‚Äôre totally right. I have to remember that withholding truth from her isn‚Äôt lying, it‚Äôs protecting myself and the people around me. I‚Äôm sorry you had a similar experience. I know for me personally it was difficult not having any mother figures in my life to help me through that time. I had to be my own mother and it was so hard. Hugs. <3

6/6. I needed to see this today, thank you. Her lovebombing and my deteriorating memory issues due to disassociating have me sometimes forgetting the fucking hell that she put me through. I forget that I had to survive being her child.

I have wondered if I had pure-O OCD after reading about it on here once. That unfortunately sounds exactly like what I‚Äôm going through, and you‚Äôre right it is pure hell sometimes. My obsessive and intrusive thoughts get out of control to the point where I get suicidal ideations or think I‚Äôm ‚Äúbroken‚Äù somehow. I‚Äôve done EMDR and DBT with little success. Does medication help with controlling the thoughts? I feel like I sometimes get into nearly psychotic states where I stop being able to tell myself I‚Äôm being irrational. I had one the other night after not having one for a while and it terrified me so badly I locked myself in my room and hid under my covers. I hadn‚Äôt done anything at all but had a bad nightmare :(

Yes. I wish I was more of a pain in the ass. I wish I snuck out, partied, went on dates, skipped class, got piercings and tattoos... My parents didn‚Äôt deserve my endless people pleasing and fawning at fucking all. I convinced myself if I was good at everything, then they would have no choice but to love me. Wrong. I just didn‚Äôt know at the time that nothing would ever be good enough for them, so I was fighting a losing battle for a decade.

You could have requested resources instead of posing this as a debate. You can do your own research if this is for a paper or something.
